elements.text: PART ONE
1. INT. DRAWING ROOM. EVENING.
A harpsichord piays — to establish that we are in the past, nothing more.
A door opens, as it does so the playing stops.
How is he?
He is sleeping, but I have never seen a man so tortured in his sleep. His brow furrows constantly. It is as if some great turmoil rages within him.
Did he say anything about what was troubling him? Has he spoken to you at all?

He has spoken for some time about painting the memories of a sunset. He talks about the sky being red like blood — no, he believes that it really is blood. Coagulated blood. No one else would see it that way, ali they would see are clouds. But if you talk to Edvard about it... (he sighs) Something has consumed him with fear.
But what? What could have caused this malaise?

He talks of a trip to Ekebergasen. He says that he was walking along the road with two friends. He was feeling tired and so he stopped, looking out over the fjord, watching the sunset. He says that the sky suddenly turned red, that blood and tongues of fire hung over the town. His friends walked on, they saw nothing, but Edvard was left trembling with fear. He claims that he heard a scream — an infinite scream passing through nature. The sadness that we see in him is because the humble means available to art are not enough for him to put that experience onto canvas. He is striving for the impossible and has despair as his religion.
What did you advise him?
This scream is still in his head so I advised him to paint it.
2. INT. REFUELLING STATION B - DAY.

A storm, but it isn’t rain battering the windows ~ it’s dust. The wind is ferocious and there is an eerie drawn out howl - a constant background scream. (Every scene set on this planet should have the same constant background atmospheric to a greater or lesser extent.) Above the storm we hear the burbling of a radio transmitter. A distress beacon starts to sound.

(Frantic) Mayday! This is third technician Jay Binks on Refuelling Station B calling Duchamp control! Come in control! Can you hear me? They're dead. Do you hear, everyone dead! Killed by the dust. By the damn dust I tell you! (Calmer) It's everywhere, can you hear it, Contrel? Hear it on the wind? It’s trying to get in!
A window smashes. The wind and screaming increases in pace.
Did you hear that? It knows I’m in here! It wants to smother me, smother me like all the others.
The wind is deafening now. More windows smash.
TECHNICIAN The planet is alive! It wants us all dead! AAAAAAAGH!
There is a terrifying gurgling scream above the noise, and then just wind and the beacon...
3. INT. TARDIS. ;
The familiar background hum of the ship in flight. Footsteps...
(Hushed) Professor? THE DOCTOR Ah, there you are, Ace. What kept you?
(Hushed) It’s a long way from the control room.”
THE DOCTOR Yes.
(Hushed) And I didn’t know the TARDIS had an art gallery...
THE DOCTOR (Whispering) Why are you whispering?
Because it feels like a museum, or a library. Somewhere serious.
THE DOCTOR (Suddenly loud) Nonsense. This is my play room. In you 60...
A door swishes open. They enter an echoey, cavernous sounding space.
What’s this, an explosion in a glass factory?
THE DOCTOR Terileptil sculpture. Such a talented race, if only they’d stick to art. Such a pity... (perky) Have you seen my Mona Lisa? It’s just down here... He sets off, Ace in tow.
Your Mona, Lisa? THE DOCTOR Yes, you remember, Ace, I told you. Leonardo actually painted seven of them. I managed to pick one up as a souvenir”
Is it the Mona Lisa? THE DOCTOR Well it’s not the one with ‘This is a Fake’ written under the paint in felt tip. That one’s in the Louvre...
Hey... Hey, hold up, Professor, what’s this doing here? THE DOCTOR Ah... The Night Watch.
Doctor, I remember this from ‘O’ level art. It’s by that Dutch dloke...* THE DOCTOR Rembrandt.

It’s meant to be one of the greatest pictures of all time. THE DOCTOR Yes, it is rather good isn't it? I picked it up from the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam in the 33rd Century. AC CAppalled) You stole it? THE DOCTOR No, no, no! Of course not!? The museum burned down. I nipped in there an hour or so beforehand. I rescued it. That’s how I got most of my collection.
You stole them. THE DOCTOR Rescued them!
You hang around waiting for museums and art galleries
to burn down or whatever - and then you loot them. It’s like grave robbing.
THE DOCTOR They would have been destroyed.
So why don't you return them? re DOCTOR What? And alter the course of history?
Huh! That’s always an argument you love to use when it ate you... (pause) So I assume we're off to nick another masterpiece, then. THE DOCTOR Nick?
Rescue, then. From where, exactly?
THE DOCTOR A backwater planet called Duchamp 331. Not a very pleasant place I'm afraid, but there’s a little something that I want to pick up.
ACE A little something that will sit in this gap.° THEDOCTOR Yes...
(Reading) The Scream, by Edvard Munch.”
THE DOCTOR Yes. According to my diary, it’s about to vanish in Inysterious circumstances...
4, EXT. REFUELLING STATION A - DAY
The same howling wind and screaming as before. Not as ferocious, but distant and constant. A door hisses open. There is a distant echoing tannoy voice.

VOICE This is Duchamp Control. AH staff on Duchamp Refuelling Base A are reminded we are on stage two storm alert. Full filtration and dust contamination procedures will be observed until further notice. Control out.
TARRANT Of all the God-forsaken planets to get stranded on... You pick ’em Bev. You really pick ‘em.
Heh! Got the dust blues girl?
TARRANT Blue would be a relief. It’s just so bleak. All this rolling grey. Endless... You must be Guthrie.
If you say so, then that’s who I must be.
TARRANT I'm Tarrant, Bev Tarrant.
Good to meet you girl. (He hawks up and spits) Be proud to shake yer hand.
TARRANT Charming.
Heh, attagiri. Spit’s a precious commodity on Duchamp. Everything’s so dry — inside and out. Dust. Gets right up the crack of
TARRANT Quite.
Yer not one of the freighter crew, are you, what’s a girl like you...?

TARRANT Doing on a dump like this? (She laughs) Bad luck, and lots of it. Got caught out by a border patrol and had to make a long hyperjump. Came out in this system with a blown hyperdrive and no fuel. (She laughs humourlessly) Six of the biggest fuel dumps in the entire sector and I've got nothing to pay for it with.
I wouldn't say that... you’re a damn fine looking woman...
TARRANT And you can forget any ideas like that...
(Gives a hacking laugh) No harm in tryin’...
TARRANT (Pause, then) They tell me you’ve been here twenty years, Guthrie. That you were here with the construction crews and you just keep extending your tour of duty. Why do you stay?
Me? Wouldn't live anywhere else. Been here since the beginning. Gonna stay till the end. (Pause) How old are you, girl?
TARRANT That's no question to ask a lady.
How old?
TARRANT Twenty nine.
Only twenty nine, eh? That’s rough. Duchamp’s no place
for the young. We're all ancient here. Old before our time. Aged by the dust. No one young ever comes here. :
TARRANT You get the long haul pilots. Ships are always refuelling here.
But no one stays. Not for long. They’re always quick to leave Duchamp. (He cackles) This is where they send you to die, girl.
8. INT. ‘GALLERY’. SALVADORI’S CABIN.
SALVADORI- Klemp? Klemp! Oh, curse the man, where is he? (Belliowing) Klemp!
(Off) Coming, Madame Salvadori.
Ah, there you are Klemp. Where the devil have you been?
Well ma’am... (taps at a keypad)
No, don’t bother, already I can feel waves of boredom sweeping over me. What of the preparations? Is the good ship ‘Gallery’ ready to embark on its great adventure to Duchamp 331?
Almost. Madame Salvadori, we are just waiting for one passenger.
Waiting for a passenger! Heavens man, we can’t delay the most prestigious social event of the decade for one passenger. Tell the captain to leave without him.
Ah, it is a rather special passenger, ma’am. Our mysterious benefactor, Mr Seta...
Ah... Well in that case... (conspiratorially) Have you made any headway in uncovering his identity, Klemp, or the nature of his mysterious and, no doubt, very expensive cargo?
I’m afraid not, Madame Salvadori. (Taps at a keypad) All investigations have met with rather... limited success.
Oh, you’re useless, I really don’t know why I keep you.
No, ma’am.
Very well, Klemp, hurry along.”
Yes, ma'am.
Oh, Klemp. Before you go. What do you think of the outfit?
Well...
Come on, man, speak up.
Well you will clash with the hors d’csuvres if you wear that particular shade of green, ma’am.
Oh, away with you, Klemp. Out, out! Shoo! (Bellowing) And bring me back something that is purple! (Hxasperated) Oh, why is nothing ever easy?!
6. INT. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM.
The Doctor and Ace approach from the access corridor.
(Distant) So where is the God-forsaken planet?
THE DOCTOR (Entering the contro] room) In the middle of the major freight shipping routes. It’s a way station. A refuelling post for spacecraft carrying supplies to the new frontier.
ACE And they decided that was a good place for an art gallery? They must run a good bus service.
THEDOCTOR (Exasperated) There is a colony of independent artists
and musicians who decided that Duchamp 331 was the perfect getaway from the rest of society.
Oh, great. Hippies.'”
THE DOCTOR Really Ace...
There is a bleep from the console, and the distress beacon from earlier.
Hey, what's that?
THE DOCTOR A distress beacon. Very faint.
He punches at controls.
ACE A ship...
THEDOCTOR No, it’s a planetary beacon... How interesting. It’s from Duchamp 331.
Professor, I don’t suppose your diary mentions exactly how this painting of yours mysteriously vanished?
THE DOCTOR No, it was rather vague.
So we’re just jumping in feet first as usual. THE DOCTOR Exactly!
Marvellous!
THE DOCTOR Honestly, Ace! Where’s your sense of adventure? The TARDIS starts to make its familiar landing noises.
7. INT. REFUELLING STATION B - DAY

Above the wind and constant faint background screaming the TARDIS starts to materialise. The door opens and the Doctor and Ace emerge. There is the bleep of a handheld device and the noise of the beacon
THE DOCTOR Yes, this is the place. The signal’s getting weaker though.

God, look at this place. (Reading) ‘Duchamp Corporation Refuelling Station B. Capacity twenty thousand tonnes.’ (She coughs) This dust... THE DOCTOR (Thoughtfully) Yes... the entire planet is dust. The refuelling bases sit on the fuel reservoir tanks floating beneath the surface, Technologically they’re quite an achievement.

It doesn't look much like a technological achievement at the moment. It looks like a bomb hit it. THE DOCTOR Yes, it’s strange, the building looks like it was blown in... The force of the wind must have been phenomenal.
It’s not exactly a summer breeze at the moment. THE DOCTOR Come on. This way... Carefully. This roof could come in any minute.”
What’s that awful screaming noise? aoe DOCTOR (Thoughtfully) I’m not sure, Ace. I’m not sure.
Well whatever it is it’s getting louder. wid Tattles the walls. THE DOCTOR The signal is coming from in here, Ace. Ace?
(Quietly) Doctor... Look. Over there, under the dust. It looks like a body THE DOCTOR Yes... and there, another. And another
Doctor, they’re all dead, aren’t they? THE DOCTOR Someone set that distress beacon going.
Then why did no one come?
THE DOCTOR I don't know, Ace. Perhaps the signal was too weak. Perhaps this dust is blanketing things somehow.
Another gust of wind rattles the base.
Come on, Doctor, let’s get out of here.
THE DOCTOR Perhaps you're right."
There is a moan of pain from nearby.
Doctor...?
THE DOCTOR Ace, over here.
TECHNICIAN The dust...
THE DOCTOR It’s all right. We're going to help.
No escape. The dust...
The wind slams in again, the screaming louder.
It’s getting worse!
THE DOCTOR Quick, help me with him.
They struggle to lift the man. There is a crash as a wall collapses. The screaming is loud now.
It will kill us all!’
ACE The entire place is coming down!
THE DOCTOR Ace! Get the TARDIS door open!
The TARDIS door opens and they bundle inside. The storm is filled with the sound of the TARDIS dematerialising.
8. INT. TARDIS CONSOLE ROOM.
That was close...
(Weak) No escape... from the dust...
THE DOCTOR How’s he doing?
I can’t see anything obviously wrong with him... He’s unconscious again. What are we going to do with him, Professor?
THE DOCTOR There are five other refuelling bases on the planet. We'll let his own people take care of him."®
What do you think happened back there?
THE DOCTOR Mysterious circumstances...
9. INT. REFUELLING BASE A. THE BAR - DAY
The clink of glasses and a steady buzz of background conversation. A door opens.
TARRANT Vodka martini. A dry one.
Heh! That won't shut the world out!
TARRANT No, but it might help dull the edges a little. You got a light, Guthrie?
Sure. (There is the klunk of an old-style lighter) Dangerous habit on a refuelling base.'°
TARRANT You're the one with the lighter.
I keeps it for... sentimental reasons.'”
TARRANT Right. (She drinks) Any news from the radio room yet? Have they got through to anyone or are we still cut off?
Still the same. Static and ghost signals. Always the same when it’s like this. We'll get nothing till this storm blows itself out. Be patient, girl. It will all be the same tomorrow.
TARRANT That’s the problem. I just don't know how you do it
Guthrie. Day in day out, the same old routine. Endless, mind numbing monotony...
The noise of the TARDIS materialising fills the room. @ What in tarnation...?!
The door opens.
THE DOCTOR Good afternoon. I'm the...
TARRANT Doctor! Ace!
Bev!
TARRANT I don't believe it! I just don’t believe it!
(Cackling) Well if that don’t take the biscuit. You’ve got
some clever friends, girl...
TARRANT What the hell are you doing here?
That’s a very long story...
THE DOCTOR That can wait for the moment. We've got an injured man who needs medical attention. Would you mind if we used your sickbay?
10. INT. REFUELLING BASE A. SICKBAY - DAY
The rhythmic background beep of medical equipment.
THE DOCTOR There...
Is he going to be all right?
THE DOCTOR Oh yes, I think so. These autodoc units are very efficient. He should be back on his feet in a couple of hours. Then perhaps he can tell us what happened.
TARRANT Who is he?
DOCTOR Jay Binks, according to his ID. A junior refuelling technician on Duchamp Station B.'°
TARRANT That's about fifty kilometres away. What happened?
Dunno. We picked up a distress signal. Went to investigate. The base was trashed. (Pause) Everyone else was dead.
TARRANT Jeez...
THE DOCTOR How come the distress signal wasn't received here?
TARRANT Communications are shot to hell. This storm. Something in the dust apparently.
THE DOCTOR Yes...
TARRANT Look there's nothing else we can do here. Let me get you a drink, and you can tell me what brings you to Duchamp 331 of all places.
You coming, Professor?
THE DOCTOR Yes, yes, I'll be right there.
The door opens and Bev and Ace leave.
TARRANT (Distant) It’s good to see you again, Ace...
(Distant) Where did you go after Kar-Charrat?
TARRANT (Distant) Oh, you wouldn't believe it... but at least it was free of Daleks...
THE DOCTOR (Mysterious) Something in the dust? Or the dust itself...
11. INT. ‘GALLERY’ BALLROOM - DAY
The chatter of a lot of people. Muted classical music, clinking champagne glasses. A knife taps on a glass.
Ladies and Gentlemen. Your attention please. (The room
quietens) Your host, Madame Elsa Salvadori. Applause.

Thank you, thank you, you are too kind. On behalf of Salvadori Entertainment — welcome! Welcome to ‘Gallery’! The most luxurious space liner ever built. I have promised each and every one of you the opportunity to bid for priceless works of art from across the known universe, but I also promise that this trip will prove unforgettable in other ways. I have commissioned a piece of art so stupendous, so unique, that all your purchases will seem shallow and ordinary in comparison. ‘Gallery’ is about to set out on a little journey, and at its end lies wonder. In the meantime, enjoy yourselves. Hat, drink and, above all,
spend! More appiause. And the music starts up again.
Wonderful, ma'am. Inspiring.
Thank you, Klemp. I thought so.
THE MASTER (His voice slightly muffled by the mask he wears — as indeed it must be until he reveals himself halfway through Scene 42) Bravo. Madame Salvadori. A most impressive speech.
Oh. Mr Seta. You startled me. I trust you are being well looked after.
THE MASTER Everything is quite satisfactory. Your staff are being most... cooperative.
After the help you have given in funding this little excursion it is the least we can do. I must admit though, to being impatient to see quite what treasures you have brought on board.
THE MASTER 0h, I assure you, Madame Salvadori, when you see what 1 have to offer, it will quite take your breath away. (He gives a racking cough)
Heavens. Are you quite all right?
THE MASTER It will pass. The journey here has left me weary. If you will excuse me. Madame. Mr Klemp.
(Conspiratorially) How much do you think that mask he wears is worth, Klemp?
(Taps at a keypad) The analyser puts the gemstones alone at three million, ma'am.
Mysterious and wealthy... I am so looking forward to getting to know our Mr Seta. Come along Klemp, we are neglecting our other guests. Mingle, mingle, mingle!
They bustle off.
THE MASTER (To himself) You will know me soon enough, Madame Salvadori. Soon enough...
12. INT. REFUELLING BASE A. THE BAR — DAY
The chatter of crew.
TARRANT ...so that’s it. Managed to get the idol, lose the patrols, and limp this far.
You could have picked a, better planet to crash on. I mean. What a dump!
TARRANT I didn’t have a lot of choice! There aren’t that many Planets out this far!
Wind rattles the windows, the distant screaming echoes around.
What is that noise?
That's the noise of Dalek madness!
You what?
TARRANT Ace, meet resident nutter, Guthrie. If he asks to shake your hand, decline.
Wotcha.
They all laugh. But old Guthrie knows the truth.
What truth?
Way back. Way before man decided that he had a use for Duchamp 331, they came here.
Daleks?
Yup.” Crippled they were. Crippled from a fire fight out

on the rim. They thought they’d land and make repairs, but they didn’t reckon on the dust. Dragged them down it did, the entire saucer, buried "em alive. Somewhere down there they are. Inside the planet, in the dust. No light, no sound, no nothin’ - enough to send any creature mad that
2? Even them tin tyrants, and now on nights like this you can hear their screams on the wind. Dalek madness... The wind rattles the windows again.

TARRANT Take no notice of him. The screams are from the only indigenous species on this hell-hole. Locals cali them dust sharks. The young scream when they’re hungry, but Guthrie sticks to his story... Don’t you Guthrie?
Hah! You'll see.
Bet he’s a bundle of fun at parties.
TARRANT ON, he’s been here longer than anyone. Actually seems to like it. But then this planet attracts nutters. If it’s not Guthrie then it’s the mob from the Outhouse.
Outhouse?
TARRANT The drop outs. Guthrie says they came up with some arty name originally, but the workers here call it the Outhouse because everything they produce is —
(Quickly) Oh right, the Doctor’s space hippies. is
TARRANT Yeah, they built their own colony out on the dust.” ‘You’ve never seen such a lash up. The Duchamp Corporation tried to evict them, but they’re stubborn and they're getting a lot of support.
How on earth do they survive out here?

TARRANT Oh they’ve got it all worked out. The freighter crews buy bits of work off them and ship things back to the homeworlds and out to the frontier.* Some of the artists are getting quite well known. It’s becoming very fashionable to have some dust art from Duchamp 331. It’s the only place that I'm able to off-load any of my...
Loot?

TARRANT Merchandise! I was going to head out there in a bit and see if I can get enough money for the idol to refuel my ship. Borrowed a dust skimmer from engineering. Interested? THE DOCTOR We'd be delighted!
Doctor! Where have you been? THE DOCTOR Just seeing if the command crew here could shed any light on the destruction of that refuelling base.
And? THE DOCTOR Nothing as yet. But the storm is easing and communications are working again.
Great.
THE DOCTOR And the commander would like us to stay around whilst they investigate.
Not so great.
THE DOCTOR So I think a little trip to the local artists’ colony is just the thing to pass the time, don’t you?
13, INT. THE OUTHOUSE — DAY We hear a radio crackle into life. An alert signal.
Yes?
(Over) That sounded a bit tetchy, my dear. I’m all for the
artistic jemperament, but is that any way to speak to your beloved atron?:
Madame Salvadori... Forgive me, 1 was... preoccupied.
(Over) I'm so very glad to hear it. And how is my
commission progressing?
DAMIEN The sketch was a success. I'm hopeful that the full work
will be ready for your arrival.
(Over) Hopeful? My dear, you have no choice. We are on
route and will be with you in exactly three hours. If you are not ready to
make me look fabulous in front of my guests then I will be angry...
But Madame Salvadori...
(Over) Very angry. And I’d hate to withdraw my
patronage. Young artists do struggle so.
There is a commotion from outside.
I must go, madame. We have visitors.
Just make sure you’re ready, Damien. Three hours.
14. EXT. LANDING BAY OF THE OUTHOUSE - DAY
A skimmer engine powers down.
TARRANT Here we are.
THE DOCTOR Extraordinary!
I see what you mean about a lash up!
TARRANT Built it all themselves. Cannibalised most of the parts from the ship they arrived in.” As more people arrive so the colony gets bigger. I’m amazed the thing stays afloat. Ah, here’s Damien.
THE DOCTOR Damien?
TARRANT Damien Pierson. Sort of leader of this bunch...
Miss Tarrant. Back again so soon?
a TARRANT Can't keep away, Damien. Brought a couple of art lovers wi me.
THE DOCTOR Good afternoon, I'm the Doctor, this is Ace.
Hiya.
Welcome to the Outhouse.
THE DOCTOR Thank you.
It’s rare we get visitors, Doctor. Was there something specific that you were interested in?
Yeah, a painting by... Ow!
THE DOCTOR No, nothing in particular. Just browsing, really.
Then allow me to show you around some of the studios.
(Walking away) Now then Miss Tarrant, you will no doubt have some more interesting artifacts to show me...
(Whispering) Professor. That hurt. If you think the painting is here then why don't we just ask muggins where it is, grab it and push off?
THE DOCTOR Because there is something else going on here, and I want to find out what it is. Mysterious circumstances, remember...
15. INT. ‘GALLERY’ HOLD.
The sound of the party is distant. We hear the footsteps of a lone security guard,

Check the hold they say. Never check the bar, or check out. the cold buffet, or check to see if the beds are comfortable. Always check the hold. I mean, what do they think I’m going to find? The boxes are checked at customs at the departure lounge. Then security do a sweep before the crates are loaded, then shipboard security do another check before the robots bring the crates down here. But no, every time we start a journey it’s, ‘Albert, go down to the hold and check the crates,’ whilst the nobs enjoy themselves at the champagne reception. And here they are. Crates. Dozens of them, All checked and accounted for, all of them... (There is a crash from one side and a scuffle) Hey, who's there?” (Another scuffle) There’s no point trying to hide, I can see you, so come out.” (Another scuffle)
THE MASTER I apologise. I was just checking that my... cargo was secure.
It’s Mr Seta, isn’t it? Look, sir, this is a restricted area. No guests are allowed in the lower levels. I’m afraid I'm going to have to report you to the captain.
THE MASTER Really. How unfortunate...
Really, sir there’s no need to... what are you doing? No! Keep back! NO! AAAAAAAAAARGH!
There is the high pitched whine of a weapon, and @ scream.
16. INT. THE OUTHOUSE - DAY
The Doctor and Ace are being shown around.
So as you can see, we cover just about every discipline. Fine art, sculpture, textiles. E It’s wicked.
THE DOCTOR ‘You have some very talented people here Mr Pierson.
A door opens. Bev steps in.
TARRANT Doctor...
THE DOCTOR Hm?
TARRANT I've just had a message from Guthrie. The technician you found — Binks. He’s dead.
Dead?
THE DOCTOR That's preposterous. He should have made a full recovery.
TARRANT The commander wants us 3 back.
Problems, Doctor?
THE DOCTOR Yes. Something’s come up as it always does. I'm afraid ]’m going to have to leave.
I’m sorry to hear that. There’s still a lot to show you.
Hey, could I stay, Doctor?” THE DOCTOR Are you sure?
‘Yeah. I like it here. It’s like Camden market gone mad.
THE DOCTOR Right. We’ll be back later.
TARRANT Have fun. ; THE DOCTOR Oh and Ace... (low) Keep your eyes open for anything...
. moysterious. Right, Doctor.
17, INT. ‘GALLERY’ BALLROOM. 5 The party is in full swing now. Salvadori is mingling with her guests.
Madame Salvadori.
Oh, what is it Klemp?
If I might have a word...
Oh, honestly. If you will excuse me ambassador... You are a gooseberry, Klemp, a total gooseberry.
There has been an incident in the hold, ma’am.
Incident? What the devil do you mean by an incident? KLEMP A murder, madame. One of the guards.
Murder? On my ship? How? When?
I think you should come and see for yourself...
18. INT. REFUELLING BASE A. SICKBAY.
The medical equipment that once beeped rhythmically now gives out a Jong flat note. A door opens.
TARRANT Well?
THE DOCTOR The crew here are at a loss. The medical computer indicated that he was fine.
TARRANT So what now?
THE DOCTOR I’ve persuaded the commander to let me do an autopsy.”
TARRANT Man of many talents, aren’t you, Doctor...?
THE DOCTOR And in the absence of Ace, you’ve just volunteered to be my assistant!
19. INT. ‘GALLERY’ HOLD.
Here we are, madame.
Oh that’s grotesque. Grotesque. I feel quite ill.
arian I must admit to never having seen anything like it efore.
Cover it up. Cover it up! Who was he?
(Taps at a keypad) Albert Bootle, ma’am, security guard.
Thank heavens it wasn’t one of the guests. What was the man doing down here?
Checking on the cargo. It seems likely he disturbed an intruder.
SALVADORI An intruder? In the hold? With all this priceless art. It is all still here, isn’t it? Tell me its all still here, Klemp!
MP (Taps at a keypad, then) All accounted for ma‘am.
0h thank the stars.
There is one interesting fact...
Stop being needlessly melodramatic, Klemp! Out with it!
It would appear that our intruder was tampering with the eargo of our masked friend —- Mr Seta.
20. INT. THE OUTHOUSE.
A door opens.
DAMIEN And this is our gallery. A modest collection of pieces of historical value.
My ‘0’ level art teacher would have loved this.”
I'm sorry?
She used to love all this abstract stuff.** Used to be able
to waffle on for hours about the importance of form and meaning and stuff...
Yes... quite. Well, if you will excuse me, Ace, I have Matters to attend to. When you’re finished here, ask anyone and they'll direct you back A my office.
kay. Cheers. The door closes. Ace walks around the room.
All a load of Jackson Pollocks if you ask me. Hey! The girl
from Perivale hits the jackpot again. The Scream, by Edvard Munch. Yuck! Can’t see what you want it for, though Professor. Hardly the cheeriest painting.
Gradually a noise begins to build — a low throbbing. This should be one of those classic and very recognisable Doctor Who type sound effects — something like Fendahi. It get louder.
Yes. I can hear (gives a ery of pain) ...ah... Professor... (The noise builds and builds) Doctor... help..
21. INT. REFUELLING BASE A. SICKBAY.
Wind thrashes against the window
TARRANT [ think it’s going to be a while before we can pick Ace up. This storm is really building again
THE DOCTOR Well we’re going to be here for a little while anyway. I’m going to make the first incision here...
TARRANT Is this a good point to tell you that I'm a tad squeamish...? I think that I... Oh my God! Doctor. There's no blood.
THE DOCTOR No...
TARRANT That looks like...
THE DOCTOR Dust. This man’s body is full of dust. Where’s that microscope? (There is a beep of machinery) Fascinating.
TARRANT Doctor...”

SKREDSVIG: He talks of a trip to Ekebergasen. He says that he was walking along the road with two friends. He was feeling tired and so he stopped, looking out over the fjord, watching the sunset. He says that the sky suddenly turned red, that blood and tongues of fire hung over the town. His friends walked on, they saw nothing, but Edvard was left trembling with fear. He claims that he heard a scream — an infinite scream passing through nature. Gary Russell: I think it was Carrie john’s idea to have the ambassador respond. ! loved Caroline john the first time I met her at a convention in Coventry - she was refreshingly honest about everything and I wanted to work with her on one of these. When Dust Breeding came up and I knew I wanted her hubby, I'l! be completely honest, having Carrie along in the same play was the perfect smokescreen. We were able to pitch the publicity along the lines that former Who companion Caroline John was playing the wicked Madame Salvadori in a story featuring the Krill (monsters created by Mike Tucker and Robert Perry for one of their novels). As a sideline, it was, “Oh, and Caroline’s husband Geoffrey Beevers will also be along, playing the part of fellow art dealer, Seta.” Worked like a dream and Seta’s secret remained so until the end of this episode - and I made sure we never put “Mr Seta” anywhere in print! Carrie arrived on the Sunday morning and asked me if she could do Salvadori with an accent, which hadn't ever crossed my mind, as she wanted to play a character part rather than just use her own voice. A mix of Russian, Eastern Europe and Italian ended up in the mix and occasionally I felt her geography slipped between fines. Carrie, quite rightly, pointed out that Salvadori wasn’t from Earth and thus whatever she did was just the local accent of Persius Major of wherever she hailed from. Can't argue with logic like that. I asked Mark Donovan to do the voice of the unscripted ambassador in this scene. I flirted with the idea of getting him to do it as the Gulfrarg Ambassador he‘d played in the Benny adventure The Extinction Event, but as that character only spoke in expletives, the joke wouldn’t have worked here.’

118. The ‘I’ was moved to the start of KLEMP’s next line. Gary Russell: ‘Another great moment and all credit to Mike for writing it and for Carrie and Mark Donovan for pulling it off. I’ve always been fond of “the little guy” or “the assistant” who eventually dies because they‘re caught up in their master’s plans (cf Mr Fibuli or Vogel) and no matter how much of a bitch Salvadori has been to Klemp, his death resonates with her. She’s upset at his death and that’s great. Mark Donovan had done a Benny for me previously. Now i don’t think Mark will be too offended if I point out that he’s a big guy, but Klemp is clearly meant to be a bit of a wimpy, Grimtongue-like fusspot. A great thing about audio is you can cast against type — Mark’s always getting roles as bruisers and bouncers and ‘token fat guy’ because people don’t look beyond the physical. Audio has no such pigeon-holing and more than one person on meeting Mark afterwards has commented to me that they can't square the picture in their heads of Klemp with the real Mark. Which is, excuse the pun, the mark of good acting.’

120. Gary Russell: ‘Well, it wouldn't be right not to have him say it! I cannot praise Geoffrey Beevers enough - the moment he stepped into the studio, he recreated the character he‘d last played in 1980. He was concerned that he got the voice right and as I'd brought along a VHS of The Keeper of Traken I was able to show it to him. It was educational for Sophie and Sylvester who, only being familiar with Anthony Ainley, were bemused by the references to the Master’s physical deformity in the script but once they saw Geoffrey's performance in Traken, it all made sense. Geoffrey then went into the recording booth and began — and that gorgeous voice was there. We discussed various ways to differentiate between the Master with mask and sans mask and in the end settled on the effective thing of having him put his hand between his mouth and the mike, thus just deadening it enough. When he “took off the mask” he did this by slowly raising his hand during the course of his tines, and so without any of Gareth jenkins’s trickery pokery, the mask came off aurally.’

1, INT. DRAKEFELL’S OFFICE. EVENING.
Damn you, Drakefell, I cannot believe that you are being so insensitive about this!
DRAKEFELL And I cannot believe that you are being so ignorant.
Ignorant? How dare you! Have you any idea what it is you're doing here?
I am perfectly aware of what I’m doing, Mr Toller. Ensuring that industry carries on into the twenty-second century.
For God’s sake man, there’s little enough work here at the best of times. Tourism is all that keeps the village going and your plant...
Is a necessary addition to this community.

Is a prefabricated monstrosity that is driving the visitors away in their droves! You’re destroying this community! It’s not as if you’ve even taken on any staff -— that at least would show some responsibility!
I can see that this discussion is not going to get us anywhere.
Oh for heaven’s sake, surely you can see...

This meeting is at an end, Mr Toller. I am a busy man and I really haven’t got any more time to spend on endless debate. I'm sorry that you can't see what we are trying to do here, but I’m afraid that there is nothing that you can do to stop it. You might as well stop trying to fight it.
Right, well we’ll see about that. Good day, sir!
A door slams.

He drinks.

Yes...
MARY And about the disease that the foxes have been catching...

1 think so. Try and talk some sense into the local political mnafia. Pll go on to London if I have to.

NOTES: Russell: ‘Guthrie's dialogue throughout the script you're reading is quite different in style and colloquiatisms to what we ended up with. Mike Tucker wrote Guthrie as an old space prospector, a sour, dour ancient American. I asked Ed Bishop to play the part but for reasons I never got told, his agent said no at the last minute (I was very pleased when we managed to get him years later into Full Fathom Five, one of the Doctor Who Unbound plays) and I had to start casting again with only a few days to go. lan Ricketts was a voice tutor at Nick Pegg’s old drama alma mater, Guildford, so I asked him, as age was more important than accent. lan was terrific but we rewrote as we went along changing the Americanisms to things lan was more comfortable with.’

We were able to pitch the publicity along the lines that former Who companion Caroline John was playing the wicked Madame Salvadori in a story featuring the Krill (monsters created by Mike Tucker and Robert Perry for one of their novels). As a sideline, it was, “Oh, and Caroline’s husband Geoffrey Beevers will also be along, playing the part of fellow art dealer, Seta.” Worked like a dream and Seta’s secret remained so until the end of this episode - and I made sure we never put “Mr Seta” anywhere in print! Carrie arrived on the Sunday morning and asked me if she could do Salvadori with an accent, which hadn't ever crossed my mind, as she wanted to play a character part rather than just use her own voice. A mix of Russian, Eastern Europe and Italian ended up in the mix and occasionally I felt her geography slipped between fines. Carrie, quite rightly, pointed out that Salvadori wasn’t from Earth and thus whatever she did was just the local accent of Persius Major of wherever she hailed from. Can't argue with logic like that. I asked Mark Donovan to do the voice of the unscripted ambassador in this scene. I flirted with the idea of getting him to do it as the Gulfrarg Ambassador he‘d played in the Benny adventure The Extinction Event, but as that character only spoke in expletives, the joke wouldn’t have worked here.’

I’ve always been fond of “the little guy” or “the assistant” who eventually dies because they‘re caught up in their master’s plans (cf Mr Fibuli or Vogel) and no matter how much of a bitch Salvadori has been to Klemp, his death resonates with her. She’s upset at his death and that’s great. Mark Donovan had done a Benny for me previously. Now i don’t think Mark will be too offended if I point out that he’s a big guy, but Klemp is clearly meant to be a bit of a wimpy, Grimtongue-like fusspot. A great thing about audio is you can cast against type — Mark’s always getting roles as bruisers and bouncers and ‘token fat guy’ because people don’t look beyond the physical. Audio has no such pigeon-holing and more than one person on meeting Mark afterwards has commented to me that they can't square the picture in their heads of Klemp with the real Mark. Which is, excuse the pun, the mark of good acting.’

I cannot praise Geoffrey Beevers enough - the moment he stepped into the studio, he recreated the character he‘d last played in 1980. He was concerned that he got the voice right and as I'd brought along a VHS of The Keeper of Traken I was able to show it to him. It was educational for Sophie and Sylvester who, only being familiar with Anthony Ainley, were bemused by the references to the Master’s physical deformity in the script but once they saw Geoffrey's performance in Traken, it all made sense. Geoffrey then went into the recording booth and began — and that gorgeous voice was there. We discussed various ways to differentiate between the Master with mask and sans mask and in the end settled on the effective thing of having him put his hand between his mouth and the mike, thus just deadening it enough. When he “took off the mask” he did this by slowly raising his hand during the course of his tines, and so without any of Gareth jenkins’s trickery pokery, the mask came off aurally.’
